[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.1 Purpose: The GParted v0.6.0-1 defines requirements for a partition manager supporting disk management tasks.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.2 Scope: GParted provides tools for creating, resizing, and formatting partitions across file systems.

[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.1 System Interfaces: GParted integrates with GNU Parted libraries and system utilities for device management.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.2 User Interfaces: GParted provides a GUI with menus, toolbars, and graphical partition representation.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.3 Hardware Interfaces: GParted supports IDE, SATA, RAID controllers, and USB devices.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.4 Software Interfaces: GParted relies on GNU/Linux-based utilities for partition operations.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.5 Communications Interfa: GParted supports network setup via dhclient for updates.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.6 Memory Constraints: GParted runs on low-resource systems with minimal memory requirements.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.7 Operations: GParted operates as a LiveCD application without requiring installation.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.8 Site Adaptation Requir: GParted is configurable for administrators and casual users.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.9 Interfaces with Servic: GParted links with backup and cloud storage services for partition management.

[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.4 Product Functions: GParted supports partition creation, deletion, resizing, cloning, and file system formatting.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.5 User Characteristics: GParted is designed for system administrators and casual users managing disk partitions.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.6 Limitations: GParted relies on GNU/Linux and libparted for core functionality.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.7 Assumptions and Dependencie: GParted assumes compatible file systems and hardware support.
[SUBSEC] 1.8 Definitions: LiveCD: Bootable media runs software without installation.
[SUBSEC] 1.9 Acronyms and Abbreviations: RAID: Redundant Array of Independent Disks

[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-001: The system shall integrate with GNU Parted libraries for partition operations.
[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-002: The system shall support GUI and CLI interactions.

[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-001: The system shall allow users to create, delete, resize, and format partitions.
[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-002: The system shall support file system labeling and integrity checks (REQ-FUNC-001).
[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-003: The system shall enable partition cloning and migration for disk management (REQ-INTF-001).

[SUBSEC] 2.3 Usability Requirements.REQ-USAB-001: The system shall provide an intuitive GUI with graphical disk representation.
[SUBSEC] 2.3 Usability Requirements.REQ-USAB-002: The system shall include help documentation and warnings for critical actions.

[SUBSEC] 2.4 Performance Requirements.REQ-PERF-001: The system shall process partition modifications within 5 seconds on standard drives.
[SUBSEC] 2.4 Performance Requirements.REQ-PERF-002: The system shall support drives up to 2TB without performance degradation.

[SUBSEC] 2.5 Logical Database Requiremen.REQ-DB-001: The system shall maintain logs of partition changes for auditing (REQ-FUNC-001).
[SUBSEC] 2.5 Logical Database Requiremen.REQ-DB-002: The system shall store configuration settings for user sessions.

[SUBSEC] 2.6 Design Constraints.REQ-DSGN-001: The system shall adhere to the GNU License version 2.
[SUBSEC] 2.6 Design Constraints.REQ-DSGN-002: The system shall be compatible with major Linux distributions.

[SUBSEC] 2.7 Standards Compliance.REQ-COMP-001: The system shall comply with POSIX standards for interoperability.

[SUBSEC] 2.8 Software System Attributes.REQ-ATTR-001: The system shall log critical actions and provide error notifications.

[SEC] 3. Verification: Unit, integration, and user testing for compliance.
[SEC] 4. Supporting Information: Manuals, configuration guides, and online documentation.
[SEC] 5. References: GParted official documentation, SourceForge project page, and POSIX standards.
